awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: NSFGEO-NERC: Aeolian dust responses to regional ecosystem change
awd_abstract_narration:
Wind erosion and dust emissions from global drylands impact ecosystem health, agricultural production and food security, human health and climate. Despite extensive study of how wind erosion and dust emission occur, and how they affect Earth's atmosphere and human populations, little is known about where, when, and why the processes take place across different ecosystems, or how changes to Earth's ecosystems influence their rates at different locations over time. Understanding these interactions is important for land managers to identify where wind erosion and blowing dust may be a problem and act to sustainably manage agriculture and ecosystems over the long term. This research will examine how different types of ecosystem change occurring across North America due to human disturbances, drought, fire and invasive plant species impact rates of wind erosion and dust emission. The research will promote international collaboration among researchers in the United States and United Kingdom as part of a NSF/GEO-UK NERC project. It will produce new information that supports management of North American drylands and will generate educational materials for K-12 students and provide scientific training to underrepresented undergraduate and graduate students.

The research will establish wind erosion dust emission responses to regional ecosystem changes across North America due to three disturbance regimes: 1) numerous discrete, small scale (<10 ha), abrupt ecosystem changes associated with energy (oil and gas) development; 2) discrete, large scale (>1000 ha), abrupt ecosystem change associated with fire and ecological feedbacks that promote invasive grasses and altered fire-wind erosion regimes; and 3) diffuse, large scale (>1000 ha), pervasive ecosystem changes associated with sustained shrub invasion of desert grasslands. New aeolian (wind-driven) sediment transport models driven by remote-sensing and broad-scale standardized ecological datasets will be used to resolve the impacts of the regional ecosystem changes on wind erosion and dust emission. The models will be calibrated using data from US National Wind Erosion Research Network sites, then applied to explore patterns of dust emission across North America. National ecological datasets will be used to analyze the drivers and interpret dust emission responses to regional ecosystem changes across the disturbance regimes. The research will significantly improve our understanding of the coupling between the dust cycle and anthropogenic drivers of ecosystem change. This project is jointly funded by the Geomorphology and Land-use Dynamics Program, the Ecosystem Science Program, and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR).

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This research project has provided new insights into the sensitivity of aeolian (wind-driven) erosion processes in dryland ecosystems to different types of disturbance. We have established where and when wind erosion and dust emission occur, and why, across dryland ecosystems of the US. Through these analyses, we have quantified how wind erosion and dust emission change in environments affected by oil and gas development, which was found to have a small but environmentally significant effect on regional dust emissions. We described spatial patterns and controls on wind erosion in the Great Basin and quantified the effects of invasive annual grasses (Bromus sp.) and accelerated wildfire cycle on potential wind erosion. We quantified effects of shrub encroachment and the simultaneous loss of perennial grass species on dust emissions from the northern Chihuahuan Desert, incorporating dust emission responses to 100 years of vegetation change in the Jornada Basin and showing that shrub encroachment has increased dust emissions. Our research has demonstrated that the interactions between aeolian process and ecosystem disturbance and change can effectively be described using both field monitoring datasets and satellite remote sensing-based models. 

Our research has also lead to significant modeling developments. We developed a new model (AERO) that can be applied to big ecological monitoring datasets in support of wind erosion management. This has enabled new approaches for more sophisticated wind erosion assessments. Connecting AERO with the Landscape Data Commons (https://landscapedatacommons.org) has enabled us to make aeolian sediment transport and dust emission estimates available to managers along with conceptual frameworks to support interpretation based on ecosystem dynamics. We developed new approaches to testing and calibrating dust emission models. This included an approach to using Generalized Likelihood Uncertainty Estimation (GLUE) to parameterize the AERO model, and an approach to using dichotomous dust point source (DPS) observations aggregated from studies published by the global research community. The DPS approach provides the first global-scale opportunity to test dust emission schemes within dust cycle (emission, transport and deposition) models. We applied the new DPS approach to calibrate a regional dust emission model. Through these processes, we have identified and demonstrated critical errors in dust model formulation used by the climate modeling and air quality forecasting communities.

This project has improved understanding of how information about wind erosion processes can be used to support management of dryland ecosystems. For decades, wind erosion management has relied on estimates of ground cover that inadequately represent effects of surface roughness on wind erosion. As a result of our research, new models, indicators, and understanding of the interactions between wind erosion processes and ecosystem disturbances and change are accessible to researchers and land managers. This includes establishing how quantitative erosion prediction tools can be used to support widely used qualitative land health assessments on rangelands.

Finally, this project provided opportunities for research, teaching and mentoring in science to graduate, undergraduate and middle school students. Through these activities, we have focused on supporting learning and career development of minority and underrepresented groups. The project has provided graduate students with experiences and skills in research, public speaking, and liaison with government agencies. Graduate and undergraduate students were exposed to scientific methods and learnt practical skills that provide a foundation for dryland monitoring and natural resource management jobs. The Asombro Institute for Science Education successfully developed and implemented interactive lessons on wind erosion and vegetation to 1,247 4th-8th graders across southern New Mexico. These lessons will continue to be implemented beyond this project by Asombro staff members.
